translated: 4 Commentary on the Verses of the Treasury of Abhidharma, Treatise, Chapter 6
From here is the third major text, which clarifies conditions. There are two parts within this. The first clarifies the six
conditions. The second clarifies the four conditions. In the section on clarifying the six conditions, it is further divided into three parts.
The first is the clarification of the essence of the conditions.
The second is the clarification of the conditions obtaining results.
The third is the clarification of dharmas arising from conditions.
In the first section on clarifying the essence of the conditions,
the text is divided into three parts.
The first is the general indication of the names.
The second is the specific manifestation of the essence.
The third is the distinction between the three time periods.
First, as for the general indication of the names,
the treatise states:
Thus the non-associated compositional factors have been explained.
The previously mentioned arising characteristic gives rise to the dharma that is being produced.
It is not apart from the combination of the remaining causes and conditions.
What dharma is this?
It is generally asked what is called the cause and condition.
The answer is that there are six kinds of causes.
What are the six? This is a specific question.
The verse states:
The enabling, co-existent, homogeneous, and associated,
It is accepted that causes are only of six kinds.
The commentary says:
The first three lines of verse
Introduce the names of the six causes.
The fourth line
Concludes by returning to the main point.
The first is the enabling cause.
The second is the co-existent cause.
The third is the homogeneous cause.
The fourth is the associated cause.
The fifth is the pervasive cause.
The sixth is the karmic retribution cause.
This will be explained later.
The SautrÄntika school and others
Do not accept the six causes.
Because there are no sÅ«tras that speak of them.
They accept the four conditions.
Because there are sÅ«tras that speak of them.
However, within the SarvÃ¢stivÄda school,
KÄtyÄyanÄ«putra,
A great arhat,
Contemplated in a quiet room
And said that there is a sÅ«tra on the six causes.
This was transmitted by the gods and not accepted by other schools. Therefore the treatise says:
The Abhidharma masters
Accept that causes are only of these six kinds.
From here, the second part,
Explaining the essence of each.
The six causes are different.
The text is divided into six parts.
First, the first productive cause.
The verse says:
Except for itself, the rest are productive. The commentary says:
Except for itself refers to only conditioned dharmas.
It means that when conditioned dharmas arise,
except for their own substance,
their own substance is not a cause,
so it must be excluded.
The rest are productive
clearly explains the essence of the cause.
When conditioned dharmas arise,
except for their own substance, all other dharmas do not obstruct,
and are called productive causes.
Therefore, the word rest in the verse includes all dharmas.
It means that both conditioned and unconditioned dharmas are the essence of productive causes.
Therefore, the treatise says:
All conditioned dharmas,
except for their own substance,
with all dharmas
as productive causes.
Because when they arise,
there is no obstruction.
The explanation says:
Using the meaning of non-obstruction,
to explain the productive cause.
Therefore, it is known that the productive cause
is broad and includes all dharmas.
The dominant fruit is narrow, only having conditioned dharmas.ğŸ”½The cause is able to make the effect.ğŸ”½It is called the efficient cause.
The efficient is the cause.
It is a compound word of holding the profession.
If according to this meaning,
the other five kinds of causes,
are also called the efficient cause,
because they are all able to make the effect.
Why is this cause alone called the efficient cause?
The treatise says:
Although the other causes are also able to be the efficient cause,
the efficient cause has no other name.
Like the form sense base and so forth.
The general is the specific name.
The explanation says:
The remaining five causes,
all have specific names.
Only the efficient cause does not yet have a specific name.
Because it is distinguished by the other five causes.
Although this efficient cause bears the general name,
it also receives the specific name.
From here, the second,
explains the co-existent cause.
The text is divided into two parts.
First, it clarifies the co-existent cause.
Second, it clarifies the mind and its concomitants.
First, the correct explanation of co-existent causes.
The treatise states:
Thus, the characteristics of the efficient cause have been explained.
Second, the characteristics of the co-existent cause.
What are they?
The verse states:
Co-existent causes are mutually resultant, like the primary characteristics and the characterized.
The mind and mental factors that arise simultaneously.
Co-existent means
existing simultaneously.ğŸ”½Mutually resultant means
explaining the co-existent cause.
The treatise states:
If dharmas mutually
are the dominant effect,
those dharmas mutually are the co-existent cause.
The explanation states:
Co-existent function.
Co-existence is the cause, named the co-existent cause.
This is an explanation of the compound as a whole.
If the effect is co-existent with the cause, it is named co-existent.
The cause of co-existence.ğŸ”½This is an explanation of the compound as a whole.
Like the primary characteristics and the characterized, the mind and mental factors that arise simultaneously.
This refers to the substance.
There are three categories.
Like the primary means
the four primary elements.
The first category.
These four great elements,
when producing effects,
mutually rely on each other to produce the derivative form.
Therefore, they are mutually regarded as co-existent causes. The characteristics and the characterized are
the second category.
The characteristics refer to the four characteristics.
These four characteristics
and the characterized dharmas
are mutually results of each other.
This is because these characteristics characterize the characterized,
and also because the characteristics arise due to the characterized.
Therefore, they are mutually results of each other.
They are called co-existent causes. The mind and the mental factors associated with the mind are
the third category.
This refers to the mind king and the mental factors associated with the mind,
which are also mutually results of each other.
The treatise says:
This is then the co-existent cause.
Because they are mutually results of each other.
They universally include conditioned dharmas,
according to their appropriateness.
The commentary says:
It concludes the above three categories.
As for according to their appropriateness,
it means that among conditioned dharmas there are five kinds:
First, the four great elements mutually face each other.
Second, the characterized and the characteristics face each other.
Third, the four characteristics mutually face each other.
Fourth, the mind and the mental factors that are concomitant with the mind face each other.
Fifth, the concomitant factors mutually face each other, all because they are co-existent causes.
It is said that they are as appropriate.
The treatise also says:
The dharma and the characteristics that are concomitant are not mutually results.
However, the dharma and the characteristics that are concomitant are co-existent causes.
The characteristics that are concomitant are not the dharma in this case.
The explanation says:
This text is the treatise author's presentation of the SarvÄstivÄda's mutual results.
The explanation of the co-existent cause has an error.
The dharma refers to the characterized dharma.
The characteristics that are concomitant refer to the four small characteristics.ğŸ”½The dharma does not rely on the small characteristics as its characteristics.
The dharma is not the result of the small characteristics.
The small characteristics rely on the dharma to arise.
The small characteristics are the result of the dharma.
It is said that the dharma and the characteristics that are concomitant
are not mutually results.
However, the dharma and the characteristics that are concomitant are co-existent causes.
Because it follows the characteristics and causes the dharmas to transform.
The dharma is the co-existent cause for the characteristics that follow it.
The characteristics that follow it are not for the dharma.
Because the characteristics that follow it are not the characteristics of the dharma that is characterized.
The characteristics that follow it are not the co-existent cause for the dharma.
Since the dharma and the characteristics that follow it
are not mutually results,
they are called co-existent causes.
How is it that now, using the meaning of being mutually results,
the co-existent cause is explained?
This should be analyzed here.
This encourages the explanation and clarification.
From here, the second part.
Explaining the following.
This has two parts.
First, explaining the essence of the following.
Second, explaining the meaning of the following.
First, explaining the essence of the following.
The treatise states:
What are called the dharmas that follow the mind?
The verse says:
Mental factors, two restraints, those and the characteristics of the mind,
Are the dharmas that follow the mind. The commentary says:
The first two lines explain the essence.
The third line concludes.
As for the mental factors,
Namely, the forty-six mental factors.ğŸ”½The two types of discipline refer to the discipline of meditation and the undefiled discipline.
These two types of discipline
exist when one enters concentration,
but do not exist when one emerges from concentration.
They are called mental concomitants.ğŸ”½The characteristics of those and the mind
Those refers to the mental factors mentioned above.
And the two types of discipline.
The mind refers to the mind-king.
Taking the four characteristics such as arising on those dharmas,
and the four characteristics such as arising on the mind-king,
are called the characteristics.
Therefore, the word characteristics applies to the characteristics of those and the mind-king.
These dharmas are called mental concomitants, as in the above three categories.
One type is mental factors.
The second is the discipline of concentration and the path.ğŸ”½The third is the characteristics.
These are the concomitant dharmas.
From here is the second.
Explaining the meaning of concomitance.
The treatise states:
How are these dharmas called mental concomitants?
The verse says:
By time, effect, goodness, etc. The commentary says:
By time,
there are four kinds of time.
First, arising.
Second, abiding.
Third, ceasing.
Fourth, falling into one time - arising belongs to the future.
Abiding and ceasing are in the present.
If a future dharma
has not yet reached the stage of arising,
and if a past dharma
is not subsumed by the three characteristics,
then apart from arising, abiding, and ceasing, it is said to fall into one time.
These four characteristics are different,ğŸ”½but they are all subsumed under time.
That is to say, the preceding concomitant
is with this mind-king
the same in one arising,
the same in one abiding,ğŸ”½the same in one ceasing,
and the same in falling into one time.
Therefore it is called concomitant.
By effect, etc.,
effect refers to one effect.
The same includes one ripening and one outflow.
That is to say, the preceding concomitant is with the mind the same in obtaining one effect,
the same in producing one ripening,
and the same in obtaining one outflow.
It is called concomitant with the mind.
This word one effect intends to take the effect of human effort and the effect of disconnection.
Therefore, the other-powered nature is different from the karmic maturation nature and the nature that is the same outflow.
It is said to have a separate fruit.
However, the effect of the dominant condition
generally has four kinds.
The first is the simultaneously arisen dominant effect.
This is further divided into two.
The first is the simultaneous and associated causes.
The dominant effect of mutual assistance.
The second is the simultaneous and other.
The effect of acquisition.
The second is the immediately antecedent dominant effect.
This is also divided into two.
The first is the immediately antecedent condition.
The effect that is produced.
The second is the immediately antecedent and other.
The effect of acquisition.
The third is the dominant effect that is separated.
This is further divided into two.
The first is the effect of karmic maturation.
The second is like a farmer who plants in spring and harvests in autumn.
The dominant effect that is separated.
The fourth is the dominant effect that is non-arising.
This refers to the cessation obtained through contemplation.
The essence is non-arising. The phrase this one effect
within the simultaneously arisen dominant effect.ğŸ”½Only takes the simultaneous and other.
The effect of acquisition.
Within the immediately antecedent [effect].
Excluding the similar nature dharmas that are immediately antecedent conditions.
Because the similar nature immediately antecedent conditions are included in the homogeneous cause.
It takes the other karmic maturation natures as immediately antecedent conditions.
In the case of the distant,
it excludes the karmic maturation fruit.
Because the three fruits are included in the karmic maturation.
It takes the other distant [conditions]
as the distant dominant fruit.
And it takes the fourth non-arising dominant fruit.
Therefore, the word one fruit
only includes the dominant fruit and the fruit of separation.
As for the good, etc.,
it also includes the unwholesome and indeterminate.
It is said that this concomitant [dharma] is the same as the mind
in being good, unwholesome,
and indeterminate.
It is called mind concomitant. The treatise says: It should be known that the former one and the latter one
show simultaneity and commonality.
Their meanings are not the same.
The explanation says:
The former word one
shows simultaneity at the same time.
The latter word one fruitğŸ”½shows the common one fruit.
For this reason, the ten causes
are called mind concomitants.
It is said that there are four kinds of time.
The three kinds of fruits, etc.
The three kinds of good, etc.
These are the ten causes.
The treatise says:
The mind king is the least.
It is the co-existent cause of fifty-eight dharmas.
Namely, the ten great fundamental mental dharmas,
their forty primary characteristics,
the eight primary characteristics of the mind,
and the secondary characteristics.
These are called the fifty-eight dharmas.
Among the fifty-eight,
excluding the four secondary characteristics of the mind,
the remaining fifty-four
are the co-existent causes of the mind.
The explanation says:
The fifty-eight are
the ten great fundamental mental dharmas such as feeling.
On top of these ten dharmas,
each has the four primary characteristics,
making forty.
Adding to the previous total, it becomes fifty.
The four primary characteristics on top of the mind king,
the four primary characteristics,
and the secondary characteristics,
make fifty-eight in total. The mind king is the co-existent cause of these fifty-eight dharmas.
The fifty-eight dharmas
are the effect of human effort.
Among these fifty-eight,
excluding the four small characteristics above the mind king,
the remaining fifty-four dharmas,
are the co-existent cause of the mind king.
The mind king is the effect of human effort.
That is to say, the mind does not rely on the characteristics of the secondary characteristics.
However, because the secondary characteristics arise in dependence on the mind,
the secondary characteristics are only the effect in relation to the mind, and not the cause. There are eight pairs of dharmas that are co-existent dharmas but not co-existent causes.
Therefore the treatise says:
Those that become causes by means of the co-existent cause, they must be co-existent.
Or there are co-existent [dharmas] that do not become causes by means of the co-existent cause. This is the thesis.
That is to say, the secondary characteristics,
each in relation to its own primary dharma. This is the first pair. The secondary characteristics,
do not have each other as their primary dharmas.ğŸ”½Although they are co-existent with the primary dharmas,
they are not the co-existent cause of the primary dharmas.
These various secondary characteristics,
each in relation to each other. It is explained:
This is the second pair.ğŸ”½That is to say, the secondary characteristics,
only have the characteristics of the primary characteristics.
They do not mutually give rise to each other.
When comparing them with each other,
they are not the same in having the same effect, etc.
Therefore, although they exist simultaneously,
they are not coexistent causes.
The dharmas that accompany the mind
[The commentary says:]
This is the third pair.
Above the dharmas that accompany the mind,
the four small characteristics are compared with the mind king.ğŸ”½They are not the same in having the same effect, etc.
They are not coexistent causes.
These various characteristics
are compared with each other in pairs, this is the fourth pair.
Above the dharmas that accompany the mind,
the characteristics that accompany the mind are compared with each other.
They are not mutually effects.
The principle is not a cause.
All that arises simultaneously,ğŸ”½the resistant, derivative form,
are compared with each other in pairs.
[The commentary says:]
This is the fifth pair.
Like form, sound, etc.,
are the resistant, derivative form.
Although they exist simultaneously,ğŸ”½they are not the same in having the same effect, etc.
They are not coexistent causes.
The partially coexistent,
non-resistant, derivative form,
The explanation continues.
The sixth pair is the pair of form with resistance and without resistance.
This refers to the unmanifested form of the prÄtimoká¹£a precepts.
The seven unmanifested forms,
although existing simultaneously,
by mutually comparing each other,
are not of the same fruit, etc.
They are not co-existent causes.
The two unmanifested forms of concentration and the path are distinguished.
It is said to be partial.
All co-arisen derivative form and the primary elements,
mutually comparing each other, the explanation continues.
This is the seventh pair.
Derivative form refers to the derivative.
The primary elements refer to the primary.
The primary and the derivative, mutually comparing each other,
are not of the same fruit, etc.
They are not co-existent causes.
All co-arisen
attainments and the attained,
mutually comparing each other, the explanation continues.
This is the eighth pair.
However, the attainment simultaneous with a dharma
and the dharma that is attained,
although existing simultaneously,
this attainment may be prior
or posterior.
Or they may arise together.
Therefore, because they are not fixed,
they are not co-existent causes.
From here, third,
clarifying the similar cause.
The treatise states:
Thus, the characteristics of co-existent causes have been explained.
The characteristics of the third, similar cause,
what are they?
The verse states:
Similar causes are similar, arising before in the same realm.
The path is mutually nine grounds, only equal and superior are the fruits.
Arising from added effort is also like this, such as those accomplished through hearing and contemplation.
The commentary states:
Similar causes are similar.
This refers to the five wholesome aggregates.
With the five wholesome aggregates.
Mutually corresponding to each other, they are similar causes. The term mutually means:
Like the form aggregate, which is the cause of form.
It is the cause of the other four aggregates.
The other four aggregates, etc.
Are all called causes in relation to form, etc.
The defiled with the defiled.
The indeterminate with the indeterminate.
The five aggregates corresponding to each other should also be understood in the same way.
The same is true for speech.
It is the same as the previous five aggregates of goodness.
They are also causes for each other.
Arisen previously in the same category and stage.
As for the same category,
within similarities,
only the same category is taken.
As the homogeneous cause.
Not all similarities are the homogeneous cause.

The category refers to the five categories.ğŸ”½That is, that which is to be eliminated by seeing suffering up to that which is to be eliminated by cultivation. Here, that which is to be eliminated by seeing suffering
only serves as the homogeneous cause for that which is to be eliminated by seeing suffering, up to that which is to be eliminated by cultivation.
Only serves as the homogeneous cause for that which is to be eliminated by cultivation.ğŸ”½As for the same stage,
it distinguishes the other stages within the same category.ğŸ”½Within the same category,
only the same stage is taken.
As the homogeneous cause, not the other stages.
The stage refers to the nine stages.
That is, the desire realm, the four meditations, and the four formless realms.
Like the desire realm seeing suffering,
only serves as the homogeneous cause for the desire realm.
Up to the peak of existence,
only serves as the homogeneous cause for the peak of existence.
are the homogeneous causes.
Because the categories and realms of contaminated dharmas are all fixed.
When compared with different stages, there is no meaning of being a cause.
The previously arisen means
within one's own stage,
only taking what has previously arisen as a homogeneous cause.ğŸ”½The past in relation to the present and future is called previously arisen.
The present in relation to the future is called previously arisen.
Therefore, the word previously arisen only applies to the past and present.
If in the past,
it is a homogeneous cause for the present and future.
If in the present,
it is a homogeneous cause for the future.
The path mutually has nine stages means
the previous statement of one's own stage
is based on speaking of contaminated [dharmas]. If the uncontaminated path is mutually compared with the nine stages,
they are all mutually uncontaminated [dharmas].
The nine stages are
the preliminary stage,
the intermediate stage,
the four meditations,
and the three formless [absorptions].
Based on these nine stages,
the uncontaminated path is aroused.
Each of them is the cause for the nine stages.
Based on the preliminary stage,
Giving rise to the uncontaminated path.
It can be the cause of the path and truth of the nine grounds.
Up to the sphere of nothingness.
Giving rise to the uncontaminated path.
It is also the homogeneous cause of the nine grounds.
The treatise says:
This [uncontaminated path] abides as a guest in all grounds.
It does not fall into the category of realms.
It is not grasped by the craving of any ground as its own.
Therefore, although the paths of the nine grounds are not the same, they are mutually causes for each other.
Because they are of the same type.
The explanation says:
The uncontaminated is not bound to the realms.
Although it arises in all grounds,
it is like a guest abiding.
It is grasped by contaminated craving.
Therefore it falls into the category of realms.
If the uncontaminated dharmas
are not grasped by the craving of the nine grounds as their own,
then the uncontaminated path
does not fall into the category of realms. Only equal or superior are the fruits distinguishes the differences.
However, it can only be the cause for the equal or superior,
not the inferior cause.
Because it is born from applied practices.
How can it be that after much effort,
inferior dharmas become its effect?
Therefore, it is a homogeneous cause for equal and superior [dharmas].
For example, the forbearance of the dharma of suffering that has already arisen,
still with the forbearance of the dharma of suffering in the future,
is a homogeneous cause.ğŸ”½This is called an equal cause.
If the forbearance of the dharma of suffering
is a homogeneous cause for the knowledge of the dharma of suffering up to the knowledge of non-arising,ğŸ”½this is called superior.
Because knowledge is superior to forbearance.
Extensively speaking, up to the knowledge of non-arising,
only with its equal class is it a homogeneous cause.
Because there is no dharma that is superior to the knowledge of non-arising.
Moreover, the already arisen path of seeing, path of cultivation,
and path of no-more-learning,
according to their order,
with three, two, and one,
are homogeneous causes.
The explanation says:
The path of seeing is a cause for three,
the path of seeing, cultivation, and no-more-learning.
The path of cultivation is a cause for two,
excluding the path of seeing.
The path of no-more-learning is the cause of one [type of path].
Excluding the paths of seeing and cultivation.
Moreover, in this context,
the paths of dull faculties
are the homogeneous causes of the dull and sharp [faculties].
The paths of sharp faculties are the causes of the sharp faculties.
Like the one who practices according to faith,
and the one who attains by faith and understanding,
and the path of liberation at the right time.
According to their order,
they are the homogeneous causes of six, four, and two [types of paths].
The explanation says:
Among the two noble ones of the path of seeing,ğŸ”½one is dull,
and one is sharp.
The dull one is called the one who practices according to faith.
The sharp one is called the one who practices according to the teachings. The path of cultivation has two noble ones:ğŸ”½one is dull,
and one is sharp.
The dull one is called the one who attains by faith and understanding.
The sharp one is called the one who attains by insight.
The path of no-more-learning has two noble ones:ğŸ”½one is dull,
and one is sharp.ğŸ”½The dull one is called the one liberated at the right time.
The sharp one is called the one liberated independent of the right time.
This is based on the three paths.
There are a total of six noble ones.
Now, the one who practices according to faith is the cause of six [types of paths].
Faith-follower.
It is the cause of four.
Excluding the two noble ones of the path of seeing.
The path of occasional liberation.
It is the cause of two.
Excluding the four noble ones of the paths of seeing and cultivation.
If one is a follower of the teachings.
And one who has attained insight and is liberated independent of occasion.
According to their order.
They are the homogeneous causes of three, two, and one.
The explanation says:
A follower of the teachings.
It is the cause of three.
Namely, followers of the teachings,
those who have attained insight,
and those liberated independent of occasion.
One who has attained insight.
It is the cause of two.
Excluding followers of the teachings.
Those liberated independent of occasion are the cause of one.
Excluding followers of the teachings and those who have attained insight.
The treatise says:
The higher stages.
Are the causes for the lower stages.
What is meant by being equal or superior?
The explanation says:
This question concerns the mutual causality of the nine stages.ğŸ”½The higher stages are superior.
The lower stages are inferior.
Being the cause for the lower.
This means being the cause for the inferior.
Not equal or superior.
The treatise says:
Due to the increase of causes,
and due to the faculties,
Referring to the path of seeing, etc.,
The lower-lower level, etc.,
In the subsequent stages,
The causes gradually increase.
The commentary explains:
It answers the previous objection.
Not due to the upper and lower levels,
Causing the path, etc., to have superiority.
Although relying on the lower level,
Compared to the upper level's path,
There are two kinds of causes,
Which are called superior.
First, due to the increase of causes,
Second, and due to the faculties.
As for due to the increase of causes,
Referring to the path of seeing, etc.,
Explains the increase of causes.
Etc. includes the path of cultivation,
And the path of no-more-learning.
In the subsequent stages,
The causes gradually become superior.
Referring to the cultivation of the path of no-more-learning,
After the path of seeing,
The path of no-more-learning is after the path of cultivation,
Which is called subsequent.
Moreover, the path of seeing, etc.,
Each has nine grades of lower-lower and so on.
These nine grades and so on,
in the later and later stages,
the causes also become superior.
Just as when the path of seeing is aroused in the upper stages,
it serves as the cause for the path of cultivation in the lower stages and so on.
And the lower-lower and so on of the upper stages,
the path serves as the cause for the middle and so on of the upper path in the lower stages.
It is because the later and later stages increase the causes.
Second, by faculties,ğŸ”½the path of dull faculties in the upper stages
serves as the cause for the path of sharp faculties in the lower stages.
The treatise does not explain the faculties,
because they are easy to understand.
Moreover, the treatise says:
Although it is impossible for the two paths of following faith and following the teachings to arise in one continuum,
the already arisen [path] serves as the cause for the future [path].
The commentary explains:
This text resolves a difficulty.
The intention of the difficulty is:
The difficulty is with the previous [statement] that it is so because of the faculties.
In one body,
the path of following faith with dull faculties has already arisen,
How can it be said that the path of the sharp faculties in the upper stages is the path of following the teachings?
How can it be said that the path of dull faculties in the upper stages is the cause of the path of sharp faculties in the lower stages?
Therefore it is said that although two paths do not arise in a single continuum,
the path of practice by faith that has already arisen in the upper stages
is the cause of the future path of practice by the teachings in the lower stages.
This principle is unobstructed. The same is true for the path born of added effort.
This clarifies that contaminated dharmas born of added effort
are the same as the preceding uncontaminated ones.
Only equal and superior ones
are the homogeneous cause.
Therefore it is said that the same is true. The same is true for those accomplished through hearing, contemplation, etc.
This correctly clarifies the essence of wholesome dharmas born of added effort.
Those accomplished through hearing, contemplation, etc.
Also include those accomplished through cultivation.ğŸ”½The merits accomplished
through hearing, contemplation, and cultivation
are called those accomplished by them.
These three kinds of wisdom
are only attained through the added effort of practice.
They are called wholesome dharmas born of added effort.
Dharmas accomplished through hearing
Together with the wisdom attained through hearing,
they are the homogeneous causes.
This is called being equal.
The dharmas attained through hearing,
together with the wisdom attained through contemplation and cultivation,
are the homogeneous causes.
This is called being superior.
Contemplation is the homogeneous cause for contemplation and cultivation,
excluding that attained through hearing because hearing is inferior.
Cultivation is only the homogeneous cause for cultivation,
excluding the two of hearing and contemplation,
because the two are inferior. The desire realm has no cultivation,
because it is a scattered stage.
The two upper realms have no contemplation,
because when one raises the mind to contemplate,
one immediately enters concentration.
The formless realm has no hearing, because there is no ear faculty.
The treatise discusses the causes in terms of the three realms,
and one can understand it by reading. The wholesome of added effort is divided into nine grades.
If it is the lowest of the low grade,
it is the cause for the nine grades.
The low middle grade,
is the cause for eight.
Up to the highest of the high grade,
it is only the cause for the highest of the high grade.
